summary.p: Two folios; Shelfmark: HC.MS.03223; HC.MS.2017.0015; Qurʾānic Text: HC.MS.03223: 003:001-003:008, HC.MS.2017.0015: 003:017-003:024; Lines per page: 15; Dimensions: HC.MS.03223: 287 x 368 mm; HC.MS.2017.0015: 289 x 378 mm; Script style: kūfī; Ductus: D group; Estimated date of production: 9th-10th century. Single verse separators: the original separators consist of short diagonal row of angled gold dashes, of type 1.2.1 (Déroche 1983, p. 27). At a later date the original gold dashes have been over-painted with silver discs. Fifth verse separators: the original separators consist of short diagonal row of angled gold dashes, the same as single verses, of type 1.2.1 (Déroche 1983, p. 27). At a later date the original gold dashes have been over-painted with small silver motifs in the form of a hā’, representing the abjad value 5. Tenth verse separators: the original separators consist of small gold roundels in the text containing an abjad letter indicating the verse count, with highlights coloured with red pigment (Fraser 2017, p. 205, ill. 8). The abjad system used in the so-called Western abjad system (see Bloom 1986, p.63, Bloom 1989, p. 97). In the margins larger silver discs have been added at a later date (see Stanley 1995, p. 11, George 2009, pp. 89-91; Fraser 2017, p. 203). Sura divisions: the original sura headings consist of an illuminated horizontal band filled with scrolling vegetal designs with occasional small geometric elements. These are predominantly gold with highlights coloured with red pigment (Fraser 2017, pp. 203, ill. 6, p. 205). On several folios major areas of the gold text have been intentionally erased in a harsh manner. The present two folios are examples of this phenomenon, both have erased rectos. This phenomenon has been discussed in Fraser 2017, p. 204-5. This erasing of pages and parts of pages is not easy to explain. The correction of scribal mistakes in written copies of the Qur’an was a common feature and can be seen on a wide variety of manuscripts written in both kūfī and cursive scripts, but here much larger areas have been erased - whole pages in many cases. It is possible that this intentional erasing of the text represents another aspect of the copyist’s change of plan at the time of production, but the nature of that change of plan is not clear, since there is no obvious partition of the Qur’an that would accord with the parts of the text that have been erased. The only pattern relating to their textual clustering is that all the examples so far discovered fall in the final ten verses of Sura 2 and the first thirty verses of Sura 3, the recto of QNL.HC.MS.03223 actually bearing the erased illuminated sura heading band for the start of Sura 3. Geographical and dynastic origins: The origins, aesthetics, symbolism and production context of the Blue Qur’ān has been discussed by several scholars over the last century. The attributions range from early Abbasid Iraq (Martin 1912; Makariou 2007; George 2009); Fatimid North Africa (Bloom 1986; Bloom 1989; Bloom 1991; Bloom 2007; Bloom 2015); Kalbid/Aghlabid Sicily (Fraser 2006); Umayyad Andalusia (Stanley 1995; Makariou 2007; Fraser 2017; D’Ottone Rambach 2017). Two useful summarising articles have also been produced (Neumeier 2006; Giardino 2017), although both are now somewhat out of date. No firm conclusions can yet be drawn, and it is hoped that further research, especially scientific and codicological, may lead to a firmer consensus on the origins of the Blue Qur’ān. Date estimate: 9th-10th century. The D group scripts were prevalent in 9th and early 10th centuries. Coupled with the various theories about the patronage and origin of the manuscript, the safest suggested date range is 9th-10th century.
Recent provenance of these folios: HC.MS.2017.0015: Christie’s, London, 27 April 2017, lot 18; HC.MS.03223: Sotheby’s, London, 29 April 1998, lot 4.

support.p: The pages of the Blue Qur’ān are notable for featuring hard-point ruling, a technique for making guide-rules by scoring parallel lines into the writing surface with a sharp tool (stylus). A widespread technique in Byzantine and early European manuscripts, it was used in a small number of early Qur’an manuscripts in ḥiǧāzī script, but apart from the Blue Qur’ān, was not used in Qur’āns in kūfī scripts. However, it was used in Qur’āns in Maghribi scripts made in the Islamic west from the 12th century onwards, and this feature has been cited in the arguments attributing the Blue Qur’an to Umayyad Andalusia (Stanley 1995, p. 12; Fraser 2017, p. 207). It is not known in how many volumes the Blue Qurʾān was originally bound. Stanley has suggested that the original plan for partition into volumes may have been altered at the time of production, as evidenced by the single remaining extant full page of illumination, on which the large gold panel of decoration was placed over a page of text. The text of that folio happened to be very close to the end of the first 7th of the Qur’an, hinting that the production team, having already copied the text on that page, may have decided to bind the manuscript in seven volumes (sub‘ or manzil, see Stanley 1995, pp. 10, 109), obliging that page to be converted from a text page to a decorated page. However, several other pages have had their text erased, but without the addition of any illumination on top (including the two folios in Qatar National Library, see above), and none of these fall on or close to a sub‘/manzil partition, suggesting that this aspect needs further research in order to find a satisfactory conclusion.

summary.p: Diacritics: Letter-pointing consists of small gold dashes of the same shape as the original inter-versal markers, but occurs very rarely and inconsistently. Many pages have no letter-pointing at all, whereas some have occasional instances that do not seem to follow any pattern of usage. For example, there is no use of letter-pointing on either of the folios in QNL, but on the folio in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (33.686), letter pointing is used on a tā’ in the 12th line and another tā’ in the 14th line; and on the folio in the Museum of Islamic Art, Doha (Ms.8.2006) a ṯā’ on line 7 of the recto is pointed with three clearly visible diagonal gold dashes. There is no vocalisation. Discussion of the script: The difficulty of applying gold script onto a page of parchment means that the shapes of the letter forms of this script are less clearly defined than for calligraphic scripts written with a calamus and standard brown inks. The technique of chrysography involves the mixing of powdered gold with an adhesive substance such as gum Arabic to make a gold “ink” whose slightly viscous and grainy nature makes it more difficult to apply. Another method involved writing the script with an adhesive liquid (size, glair, gum Arabic) and then applying powdered gold (Déroche et al. 2015, p. 118). In both cases the gold script was then outlined with a thin line in a contrasting colour. Perhaps as a result of the challenges of these techniques, the gold script on the Blue Qur’an has a greater number of variations in letter forms and the categorisation of the ductus is not straightforward. In many cases different examples of the same letters relate to more than one of the sub-types of the D scripts. Françōis Déroche ascribed it to D.IV but noted several letter forms that are atypical of D.IV or even unique to the Blue Qur’an (1992, p. 43, cats. 42, pp. 92-3) and Alain George follows this categorisation, pointing out certain letter forms that he suggests are archaic within the D group as well as a related variation in the form of the word Allah (George 2009, pp. 80-81). He associated these forms with influence from styles B.II and C.III and suggested that the script of the Blue Qur’an was a transitional script, being an early expression of D scripts retaining some influence from B and C groups, and he attributed manuscript to the period c. 750-850, a period when he suggests D.IV was developing. However, observation of the present two leaves as well as many others in the known corpus reveals many variations in the letter forms, the great majority of which relate to different sub-groups within the D group of scripts, with a small number relating to other script types. This means that it is difficult to precisely define the script of the Blue Qur’an as any specific sub-group. Thus it is more sensible to define the script of the Blue Qur’an as falling generally in the D group rather than being one specific sub-type of the D group, or perhaps being a hybrid script with a foundation in D scripts. There is frequent use of mašq (“horizontal stretching of the letter forms”). A selection of the variations of individual letter forms based on a survey of many pages of the Blue Qur’ān is as follows: Different examples of initial ʾalif are close to D.I, D.II, D.III and D.IV. The lower return most often rests on the line rather than curving upwards. In this it is closest to D.III, but the end is less gradually tapering and often ends in an angled tip. In most cases the ascenders of lām-alif diverge widely, in a form close to D.I and D.II, and in some instances the form resembles D.Va, and occasionally B.II, but is not similar to D.IV. Initial ǧīm/ḥā’/ḫā’ is close to D.I, D.II and D.IV and occasionally C.III, while the medial form is close to D.I. Final form is close to D.III. Initial ‘ayn and ġayn has a more angular return than most D script examples, and its exact form lies between C.III and D.Vb. Different examples of medial ‘ayn and ġayn are close to D.I, D.II, D.III and D.IV. Déroche states that the final form is a D.IV type, but an atypical shape (Déroche 1992, p. 43). Final fā’/qāf is close to D.I and D.IV. The form of the sublinear hook has a shorter or non-existent ligature joining the upper circle to the lower hook in the present script, meaning the lower hook rests against the upper circle. Final mīm sometimes has a tail that is quite thick and straight, at other times it is a small stub that tapers to a point, and occasionally it widens to a small wedge shape. These forms most often relate to different D types, and more rarely to F. Overall most examples are closest to D.I and D.III. Final hā’ is at different times close to D.I, D.II and D.IV and D.Va. Medial hā’ is sometimes close to D.Vb and even occasionally to E. George points out that examples of the word Allah have the group of lām-lām-hā’ arranged so that the heads of each letter descend to the left in a straight diagonal line, the cluster creating a triangular form (George 2009, p. 81). He links this to influence from C.II and C.III. However, close examination shows that many examples of the word Allah do not have this form, rather, the two letters lām are almost the same height, but the hā’ is significantly shorter. Final nūn is closest to D.IV.
